csimulate module

«  lib   ::   Contents

csimulate module¶

common simulations for collective behaviours

csimulate.attanasi2014pcb(n: int, eta: float, v0: float, b: float, r: float, pre_steps: int, run_steps: int, jump: int = 1, load_file: str = '') → numpy.ndarray[float64]¶

3D Vicsek simulation in paper 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003697 (scalar noise + harmonic motion in 3D)

Parameters

  • n (int) – number of particles in the system

  • eta (float) – the magnitude of noise, from 0 to 1

  • v0 (float) – the speed in the simulation

  • b (float) – the beta parameter controlling the strength of the resotring force of the harmonic oscillator

  • r (float) – the interaction range

  • pre_steps (int) – the simulation steps running without writing to the result typically this is the simulation steps to reach a steady state

  • run_steps (int) – the simulation steps that write to the result

  • jump (int) – every jump step is writting into the result

  • load_file (str) – load initial configuration from a xyz file

Returns

the positions and velocities of particles in each frame, shape (run_steps, n, 6)

Return type

numnp.ndarray

csimulate.vicsek_2d_pbc(n: int, box: float, eta: float, v0: float, r: float, pre_steps: int, run_steps: int, jump: int = 1, load_file: str = '') → numpy.ndarray[float64]¶

2D Vicsek simulation with scarlar (intrinsic) noise and periodic boundary condition

Parameters

  • n (int) – number of particles in the system

  • box (float) – the size of the cubic box

  • eta (float) – the magnitude of noise, from 0 to 1

  • v0 (float) – the speed in the simulation

  • r (float) – the interaction range

  • pre_steps (int) – the simulation steps running without writing to the result typically this is the simulation steps to reach a steady state

  • run_steps (int) – the simulation steps that write to the result

  • jump (int) – every jump step is writting into the result

  • load_file (str) – load initial configuration from a xyz file

Returns

the positions and velocities of particles in each frame, shape (run_steps, n, 4)

Return type

numnp.ndarray

csimulate.vicsek_2d_pbc_vn(n: int, box: float, eta: float, v0: float, r: float, pre_steps: int, run_steps: int, jump: int = 1, load_file: str = '') → numpy.ndarray[float64]¶

2D Vicsek simulation with vectorial (extrinsic) noise and periodic boundary condition

Parameters

  • n (int) – number of particles in the system

  • box (float) – the size of the cubic box

  • eta (float) – the magnitude of noise, from 0 to 1

  • v0 (float) – the speed in the simulation

  • r (float) – the interaction range

  • pre_steps (int) – the simulation steps running without writing to the result typically this is the simulation steps to reach a steady state

  • run_steps (int) – the simulation steps that write to the result

  • jump (int) – every jump step is writting into the result

  • load_file (str) – load initial configuration from a xyz file

Returns

the positions and velocities of particles in each frame, shape (run_steps, n, 4)

Return type

numnp.ndarray

csimulate.vicsek_3d_pbc(n: int, box: float, eta: float, v0: float, r: float, pre_steps: int, run_steps: int, jump: int = 1, load_file: str = '') → numpy.ndarray[float64]¶

3D Vicsek simulation with scarlar (intrinsic) noise and periodic boundary condition

Parameters

  • n (int) – number of particles in the system

  • box (float) – the size of the cubic box

  • eta (float) – the magnitude of noise, from 0 to 1

  • v0 (float) – the speed in the simulation

  • r (float) – the interaction range

  • pre_steps (int) – the simulation steps running without writing to the result typically this is the simulation steps to reach a steady state

  • run_steps (int) – the simulation steps that write to the result

  • jump (int) – every jump step is writting into the result

  • load_file (str) – load initial configuration from a xyz file

Returns

the positions and velocities of particles in each frame, shape (run_steps, n, 6)

Return type

numnp.ndarray
